data.text: Stealth Camping in Europe?
What is the best resource for those who wanna camp in a tent while cycling in Europe, and has anyone stealth camped the entire way thru their tour?

Of course. Where in Europe? I am Polish, and here it's no problem at all (I was told it's officially forbidden, but truly nobody cares, unless a National Park - like everywhere a big no).. Generally, the more east, the better. Scandinavian countries seem to be a stealth camping paradise too. The Balkans, Romania, Bulgaria, Turkey - no problem. The more touristy and expensive areas, the worse - talking about some regions in Italy like Tuscany, Croatian coast, the coast in the summer in general. As for the apps, I've ever used any until recently sometimes check IOverlander, for Poland we have 2 others.
data.author: Ewa ≈öwiderska

data.text: I've been touring France for the last 3 months. Have wild camped the whole time except for 2 occasions..
data.author: Paul Wood

data.text: I stealth camped a lot in France. Nearly most of the time. Generally didn't spend too much time in cities. So I wouldn't try it in Paris. It can become a bit exhausting worrying about if you are going got get caught and moved on so you ll want to figure out that. Its often a good idea to ask locals for some idea where to camp. But also remember about that murder in France recently. If you are going to do it, stay out of sight. And if you do tell anyone locally, make sure its someone who is not likely to want to come and murder you.
data.author: Andrea Collisson

data.text:
what‚Äôs so funny, ? https://youtu.be/L4mPl_iB-bQ
The Good, The Bad & The Ugly of Bicycle Touring
youtube.com
data.author: Tony De Jesus

data.text: No offense. Just the last sentense. Of course I agree and we must be careful.
data.author: Kleanthis Kokavesis

data.text: I forgot to mention, that just because you can find a place anywhere, you are not free to do it on private property so you must be careful and respectful if you are going to do that. Never leave anything behind and do not camp on people's fields which might just look like sort of pretty weeds. It might be cattle fodder growing. If its a private place its always better to ask and often they will say yes. Not that I did that a lot but the only times I did ask they said yes.
data.author: Andrea Collisson

data.text: You can camp in Paris, the Bois de Boulogne, it used to be 21 Euros a night, maybe more now.
data.author: Maurice Robson

data.text: Lesson 1 don't tell a murderer where you're going to wild camp. Lesson 2, don't forget lesson1.
data.author: Donald Canard

data.text: Hitchhiker to driver: "Aren't you afraid of picking up an ax murderer?" Driver to Hitchhiker: "No. The probability of one ax murder meeting another is almost zero."
data.author: Peter Lehman

data.text: Finland, Norway, and Sweden have so-called 'right to roam' or 'everyman's right'. There are some modest restrictions, but camping anywhere reasonable is pretty much fair game.
data.author: Brian Jones

data.text: Yes, no stealth required except if you are within city areas. And some national parks and recreational areas have restrictions. Ask a local for a good place to put up a tent for a night and they‚Äôll usually help.
data.author: Linda Ekl√∂f

data.text: Hungary, Austria, Germany, France, Spain. Wild camping all the way. No one said anything about it. The point is far from inhabited settlements. üôÇ
data.author: Gyula Horv√°th

data.text: Yes, no problems any of the countries, if you wild camp correctly nobody will know you where there, satelite maps can help finding nice places, watch out with ticks though as they are on the rise each summer, they transmit nasty diseases, i got chronic lyme this way and preety much impossible to cure it 100% if chronic
data.author: Tomas Aperlo

data.text: I quite like my showers at night ad camping in france is so cheap 6 to 8 euros a night it's hardly worth stealth camping
data.author: John Axson

data.text: seconded, the municipal camp sites (ones run by local villages) are basic but have all the essential resources you need. They're incredibly cheap too.
data.author: Maurice Nagington

data.text: I paid 4 euros plus 1 for the tent in the pyrenees last year. Camping on a farm
data.author: John Axson

data.text: I like showers/ washing too, but the need expands the possibilities. France municipal campgrounds are good, we have same prices in Poland, but in some countries the price for campsite goes to crazy 30EUR or more do no, thank you.
data.author: Ewa ≈öwiderska

data.text: Wow, do u have a link please?
data.author: Ian Wilkinson

data.text: there's not really "a link" for the municipal campsites. Most are listed on Google maps, but many are very informally run, known about by local people, with a small sign post telling you about them as you cycle along.
data.author: Maurice Nagington

data.text: Curious as I'm planning a trip, do I need Euros to pay for campsites in France or do most take credit cards?
data.author: Alison Emily Baker

data.text: Ahh sweet. What do they charge for 1 person and a tent?
data.author: Ian Wilkinson

data.text: I've just done 15 nights and 2 sites didn't take a card so worth keeping a ew euros in your sock
data.author: John Axson

data.text: usually single figures, varies between camp sites. But they're easily the cheapest option. Don't expect staff to be on-site all the time, pools, or restaurants. Most have electricity available though. If all you want is a safe and tidy place to pitch for the night, they're perfect.
data.author: Maurice Nagington

data.text: We are big fans of wild camping and have done it in many countries in Europe with no problems. We're good at it though... as in, we rarely get found.
data.author: Cath Wood

data.text: Buy a camo or forest green tent
data.author: Maurice Robson

data.text: I pay for nothing unless I have too! Bivvy bag, and a camouflage tarpaulin, mainly used to cover the bike at night near a road. Bivvy bag so I can see what is going on, rather than a tent. Toured Spain no issue, even along the Costas! Pick a spot near dark, or during the day and come back to it at nightfall. No fires, cook in the morning when you have packed away your sleep stuff. I have used a similar principle in cities using parks. Regards the Bois De Boloigne, yes use the campsite, the park itself is notorious at night. Google it if want. Think Vice did a piece on it once. Interesting ride home from the Metro to the campsite, late at night.
data.author: John Reynolds

data.text:
https://www.vice.com/en/topic/bois-de-boulogne
Bois de Boulogne
vice.com
data.author: John Reynolds

data.text: For Denmark there is a handy app called "shelter". It shows all the free camp spots.
data.author: Sindy Sindy

data.text: Dark green tent...
data.author: Charles Dow Thomson

data.text: The iOverlander website and app is the only crowdsourced resource I've found - where people can upload sites - official and wild - they've found. It's mainly geared towards camper vans but you can filter for tenting sites too, and I've found it useful sometimes. The most useful resource is a navigation app that can show satellite imagery - very useful for finding forests or clumps of trees where you might be able to hide your tent. As others have said here, it's perfectly possible to stealth camp through all of Europe, and tracking down good sites is an essential skill you'll learn.
data.author: Tom Platts-Mills

data.text: Never done Europe, but done the us west coast a few times and sections of Se Asia. My big tip is bring a hammock. It greatly expands ur sleeping options. Rain, mud, snakes, scorpions, ants, it cooler and you can camp on steep slopes all the while having an extremely comfortable bed.
data.author: Kenny Barks

data.text: assume there are trees in the area.
data.author: Ewa ≈öwiderska

data.text: You can also use the website ‚ÄúWelcome to my garden‚Äù. Private gardens where you can camp for free.
data.author: Ingrid Wouters

data.text: I love that. I wish I was going to Europe now lol.

data.author: Eric Jenkins

data.text: If you find a good spot to camp but its a bit early - stop cycling early and camp there - you can get up earlier and catch up. If you 'just hang on for another place' it often doesnt appear
data.author: Dane Hardinge
